body:
Pasting a scrap of thoughts/impl of the record reader - https://gist.github.com/prazanna/698459049447d8898a9de11e3863e99d

@vinothchandar

Think about supporting multiple delta files - on compaction failures
Fall back of on-disk merge if the delta file size exceeds certain limit

>> Think about supporting multiple delta files - on compaction failures
Fall back of on-disk merge if the delta file size exceeds certain limit

Just a note - I guess we are okay to assume that we are able to merge in all the updates in memory with HoodieAvroReader. #134 tracks the disk spill if needed.
This requires #149 to be done first

Upon more digging, it all boils down to the following to get the merging right 

- [ ] **Projecting only requested fields in query off Avro records** 

 Reading using the a sub schema built off `conf.get(ColumnProjectionUtils.READ_COLUMN_NAMES_CONF_STR)` should do the trick. Need to test with nested records and complex data types.  Then compare to Parquet projections, in terms of order  & so forth and make sure its all good. 

http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/org.apache.avro/avro/1.7.7/org/apache/avro/generic/GenericDatumReader.java#GenericDatumReader.read%28java.lang.Object%2Corg.apache.avro.io.Decoder%29 is how the data is read in `AvroRecordReader` ([link](http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/org.apache.avro/avro-mapred/1.7.7/org/apache/avro/mapred/AvroRecordReader.java))

- [ ]  **Converting the `GenericRecord` to same `ArrayWritable`**



We need to get the types [here](http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/org.apache.avro/avro/1.7.7/org/apache/avro/generic/GenericDatumReader.java#148) and turn it into [ArrayWritable](http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/org.apache.hadoop/hadoop-common/2.7.1/org/apache/hadoop/io/ArrayWritable.java)

- [ ] **Extra projection added for `_hoodie_record_key` should be removed out in the end**

Should be zero effect to the change above
Seems to be parquet jars missing? Let me see if I did anything special locally..
Thanks @vinothchandar

I think the issue was with Hive Version. I am using Hive 2.1.0 and the examples were for Hive 1.1.1 and with CDH dependency. 
This worked for me after doing the following:

- Overhauling import statements (changing parquet.* to org.apache.parquet.*)
- Modifying dependencies in pom.xmls
- Changing a couple of method signatures since Hive 2.1.0 does not have them anymore.

Can I make a pull request?

Glad you got it working @alunarbeach 

The fix is a little tricky. We have to create profiles to support multiple hive versions. We cannot change the parquet library to use apache parquet instead of twitter parquet, because that will break support for hive 1.X versions. 

Let me think about this and let you know the best way to create a PR for this.
Thanks @prazanna.   I understand.
@alunarbeach of course, let us know if there is a way to do this easily.. may be a `hoodie-hive2` module? @prazanna ?

Not as of now.. Uber is predominantly parquet. 

ORC support needs an implementation of https://github.com/uber/hoodie/blob/6e87e79b01d6c6d8fc790403f5de5fbb50d40411/hoodie-client/src/main/java/com/uber/hoodie/io/storage/HoodieStorageWriter.java  and a new HoodieORCInputFormat that subclasses the right ORC IPF..  

You are welcome to take a stab :)

As for the design of the `InputFormat` itself, Hive seems to extend `FileSplit` across the board 

https://github.com/apache/hive/search?p=3&q=FileSplit&type=&utf8=✓ 

ORC Split : https://github.com/apache/hive/blob/ff67cdda1c538dc65087878eeba3e165cf3230f4/ql/src/java/org/apache/hadoop/hive/ql/io/orc/OrcNewSplit.java 
HBase Split : https://github.com/apache/hive/blob/ff67cdda1c538dc65087878eeba3e165cf3230f4/hbase-handler/src/java/org/apache/hadoop/hive/hbase/HBaseSplit.java

Of the two places I saw hardcoding of checks, all of them check for `instanceof`, so a subclass should be fine.  

https://github.com/apache/hive/blob/a1cbccb8dad1824f978205a1e93ec01e87ed8ed5/ql/src/java/org/apache/hadoop/hive/ql/io/parquet/ParquetRecordReaderBase.java#L82
https://github.com/apache/hive/blob/ff67cdda1c538dc65087878eeba3e165cf3230f4/ql/src/java/org/apache/hadoop/hive/ql/exec/tez/HiveSplitGenerator.java#L305
I am going to call this `StaticHashIndex` or `BucketedIndex`
@prazanna @vinothchandar any suggestions on how do you want to proceed?
I am happy with hoodie-hive2.. @prazanna is the hive registration expert.. :) Will wait for him to pitch in
@prazanna Any suggestions?

trying to understand this.. if there is a new partition, then it wont contain an existing record right..so insert seems correct to me.. 
Can you expand more or give an example for what you are referring to ?

Consider this scenario. 
I have a record with a unique id field as a key, dayid and a reprocessed indicator field as partitions.
When I reprocess a record, I update the indicator.  With the current approach, Hoodie dataset results in two records (old one and the new one) with different file ids.

By design, are partition fields expected to be part of the key?

yes. the current indexing methods we have consider partitionpath as a part of the key... the key is made of two strings:  `recordkey` and `partitionPath` (see HoodieKey.java) . your problem seems to be that the partitionPath changes between runs for the same recordKey?

See https://github.com/uber/hoodie/wiki/HashMap-Index for a proposal to make this global.. 

That said, in practice, we have noticed that the above helps us scale nicely, since most datasets have an active window for a few days and once a time passes, these records are not touched again. So, including the partitionpath in HoodieKey makes the indexing scale better.. 

Are you on the slack channel? may be we can discuss your usecase more deeply there and see what we could do?
I understand. I am not in the slack channel. I would like to explain my use case in detail. Could you please add me?
sure.. can you give me your email?
done

Thanks

- Anbu

All more follow up after chat with someone from netflix

https://medium.com/netflix-techblog/s3mper-consistency-in-the-cloud-b6a1076aa4f8 

we can potentially use something like this.
Thanks @vinothchandar . Interesting blog. Will read some more on S3amper.

As I see it, it would be a separate service on cluster checking for inconsistencies and posting them to SQS queues, and the application checks the inconsistencies before using the data. Yet to see few examples how applications use it. Will post back once I get more info.
Another potential solution is the EMRFS directly from Amazon: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/emr/latest/ManagementGuide/emr-fs.html
I heard its NFS 4 (which seems to be vastly improved now) under the hoods.. Any operational experiecne with EMRFS? Def worth checking out..

@alunarbeach - I am still figuring out the best way to do this. Please go ahead with the hoodie-hive2 module for now. If we need to change this to make it something like this (https://github.com/streamsets/datacollector/blob/master/pom.xml#L363) we will refactor this later. Would be happy to sign off a PR from you @alunarbeach - Thanks.
@ovj - Can you take a look at this please?
yeah. let me look at it.

@alunarbeach quick question. Did you look at this? https://jaceklaskowski.gitbooks.io/mastering-apache-spark/content/spark-properties.html Have you set SPARK_CONF_DIR or SPARK_HOME environment variable from where you are running spark job?
I used Hoodie-cli.sh to launch the admin console and executed this command. By default it should set SPARK_CONF_DIR to /etc/spark/conf. Let me check

[![CLA assistant check](https://cla-assistant.io/pull/badge/signed)](https://cla-assistant.io/uber/hoodie?pullRequest=163)

Thanks for the contribution! We are just looking into this at Uber for viewfs as well :). great timing.

BTW can you please sign the CLA, that will help us merge this in. 

cc @ovj can you test this out for our ingestion system as well..

Thanks @ovj.  
After I added the following export statements in  ./hoodie-cli.sh it worked.
I had to set both SPARK_HOME and SPARK_CONF_DIR though.

```shell
export HADOOP_CONF_DIR="/etc/hadoop/conf"
export SPARK_HOME="/usr/lib/spark"
export SPARK_CONF_DIR="/etc/spark/conf"
```
By default they are not exported.
Will take a closer look .. Does this now cover .compaction as well?
Also can you please merge your commits into a single one.. 3 commits feels excessive for this change
Oops missed this..
@prazanna why does it say CLA not signed for you ?
Do we still need this PR?

not yet - 
this only cleans up copy on write metadata. #165 will refactor archival of all instants,  archive all the instants into a archive timeline log (not just commits). This PR just deletes old .clean files, which is needed for copy on write now.
Wow, we almost forgot about it too.
This pull request was accidentally made against spark 1.5.1, will close this and open a new one.

Had a chat with @n3nash. We want to make sure the HoodieWrapperFileSystem is able to create block aligned files with viewfs schema as well. This was the reason we wrapped the hadoop file system and this is a good check when adding support for new file system schemes. He will update once he checks that and we can pull in the PR. 

cc @vinothchandar
Sounds good..
@ovj do you want to change the hoodie-cli.sh?
hum. probably not. These are usually environment variables you need to set as per environment. @vinothchandar @prazanna - what you guys think? create hoodie-env.sh?

These configs are good defaults. So we can add it to the hoodie-cli.sh
export HADOOP_CONF_DIR="/etc/hadoop/conf"
export SPARK_HOME="/usr/lib/spark"
export SPARK_CONF_DIR="/etc/spark/conf"

These should be documented as well. These are standard hadoop and spark settings that should be set by the user as part of the hadoop user bash profile.

LGTM. We seem to be creating .inflight commit files today additionally.. 

I do have some concerns around how `HoodieWriteClient::rollbackInflightCommits` handles a `.clean.inflight` left over by a partial cleaning.. I see savepoints being excluded from cleaning.. should we do same for cleaner (and may be delta commits and compaction) too?

Accidental Commit.
This needs to be done on top of #171 .. @kaushikd49 when are you planning to work on this
Also look at HoodieLogBlock.fromBytes
Today we return the error record with the exception - It may be better to classify this error with certain labels (INTERNAL, SCHEMA etc)
Hmmm. Can't the client figure it out based on the exception.. Going down the path of classifying exceptions into buckets inside hoodie, seems like an overkill to me.

@vinothchandar Yeah I agree that if we create exception class for every possible combination then it would be too much. But today the problem is in WriteStatus we get back Throwable and it is very hard to figure out what happened with this record. At least if we can classify them as HoodieServerException / HoodieClientException (names can be different) then still it would be helpful. That way all hoodie clients can commit current transaction if there are only HoodieClientExceptions. Thoughts?

Most systems shy away from this type of thing, since exceptions could be result of other side effects and so forth, hence having the clients decide is better.. 

Lets may be define these classes of errors and take this forward, if there are significant benefits?
Looking
Looks like travis stopped pulling in from configured 3rd party repo (for us it is cdh repo) and is just going to use maven central. Trying to figure out what could be a solution to this.

Not as bad as i initially thought. Travis can still contact 3rd party repo. The cdh url changed. 
https://github.com/uber/hoodie/commit/e1d13f2bc8adf78f6413dda7fd3b38d711a1417a

Build passed: https://travis-ci.org/uber/hoodie

Conservatively, by end of week, mostly by EOD tmrw. I strongly encourage to wait for the filegroups to be in, before you go there, coz what you need is to ultimately parallelize by file groups.
Ok, that would be great. I'll wait for it to go in before.
Awesome..
@kaushikd49 and I chatted offline and decided to decouple the efforts..

https://hackernoon.com/extending-our-spark-sql-query-engine-5f4a088de986 is an example for writing a datasource
https://michalsenkyr.github.io/2017/02/spark-sql_datasource

https://github.com/cloudera/Impala/blob/cdh5-trunk/fe/src/main/java/org/apache/impala/catalog/TableLoader.java#L69 might be coming from this. My guess is we need a fix to https://github.com/cloudera/Impala/blob/cdh5-trunk/fe/src/main/java/org/apache/impala/catalog/HdfsTable.java

As far as I see, the input format is instantiated there.. so,there is hope. but needs some work. I have 0 exp with impala
@gekath is taking a stab at it.
Sounds good. all yours

Here is a brain dump on this.. Feel free to pick the first subset of this list, to get started. 

**Goal:** 
Ultimately, 
 - Subsume most functionality of `HoodieWriteClient` for saving a dataframe back into a hoodie dataset, including all two storage types (COPY_ON_WRITE, MERGE_ON_READ) 
 - Subsume most functionality of `HoodieReadClient` for running queries on a Hoodie dataset - including all three views (ReadOptimized, RealTime, IncrementalView)

For starters, 
May be just support COPY_ON_WRITE & ReadOptimized/IncrementalView. 
A good test would be that 
 - the `HoodieDeltaStreamer` will be able to use this to write data (all the things that are configurable like key extractors, schema providers etc... can be provided as options to datasource)
- dataset can be queried incrementally (currently done by `HiveIncrementalPuller` or `HoodieReadClient::readSince`, `HoodieReadClient::readCommit` methods) or normally via the datasource like `HoodieReadClient::read(paths)`. 

**Writing** 

- Main thing here is to support modes for : upsert, insert, bulkInsert & if/how the saveModes map to these.. https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/sql-programming-guide.html#save-modes 
- User is able to specify a `key-generator-class` to control, record key and partition path as in DeltaStreamer
- Internall payload will just be something (say HoodieRowPayload) that converts Row to GenericRecord, so we can probably fix this. May be for first cut, all we do is blindly replace the existing value with the provided record and we can leave this part pluggable where, by extending the HoodieRowPayload (all of this again stems from HoodieDeltaStreamer) 
- Schema is in the dataframe, so we need not worry about that. 


**Reading** 
- We can simply wrap the parquet source with additional filtering like in `HoodieReadClient::read` for normal queries.  (This already gives a DataSet/DataFrame)
- Tricky things are how we support incremental queries and how to specify commit time for this. A powerful way is to have special columns right in the query like  
  ```
  select * from table where a = 1 // this does a normal query 
  select * from table where _mode = incremental and _commit_time_start = "20171020120102" // this is a incremental query
  ```
Don't know if this makes sense or doable. Something to ponder. Of course easier thing is to specify the mode & commit time as options for the `spark.read....` 

- Need to find a way to support `read(RDD<HoodieKey> keys`, kind of like a point look up query.. but may be better to leave it out also and support only like the `HoodieReadClient` 


Once we have a basic datasource, we will integrate support for hive sync and merge-on-read and  and a structured streaming sink (in that order). Fun stuff
@zqureshi here you go.. cc @prazanna

Made changes incorporating your above comments.

Just summarizing the current behavior, as long as the filesystem config is on the class path, `FsUtils.getFs()` will do the right thing and load the correct filesystem object, using the scheme i.e  `hdfs://tmp/dataset1` will talk to hdfs & `s3a://tmp/dataset1` will talk to s3.. 

Can you expand the use case here more with an example? I think we are trying to read from gcs and write to hdfs.. is that the use case?

[![CLA assistant check](https://cla-assistant.io/pull/badge/not_signed)](https://cla-assistant.io/uber/hoodie?pullRequest=186)
Thank you for your submission, we really appreciate it. Like many open source projects, we ask that you sign our [Contributor License Agreement](https://cla-assistant.io/uber/hoodie?pullRequest=186) before we can accept your contribution.
You have signed the CLA already but the status is still pending? Let us [recheck](https://cla-assistant.io/check/uber/hoodie?pullRequest=186) it.

> `FsUtils.getFs()` will do the right thing and load the correct filesystem object, using the scheme

So this will pick up the right filesystem configured via `fs.defaultFS` in the config.

We were thinking of a case where we would like to read from HDFS and say write to GCS, yep.
@gekath had been tracking down consumers of `getFs` yesterday and trying to figure out what the best way to thread the URI would be.
@zqureshi Also current Google Storage support for Hoodie restricts read and write to be done on the same bucket.

@vinothchandar instead of relying on fs config being on classpath, looking into getting filesystem according to provided URI. Most calls to getFs() have access to a config or spark context. Was thinking to set the URI in config or spark context. Then getFs() can get corresponding filesystem, otherwise it will return default filesystem. Thoughts?

> Then getFs() can get corresponding filesystem, otherwise it will return default filesystem. Thoughts?

If you have the right scheme in the path `hdfs` or `gcs` or `s3`, getFileSystem() , will do the right thing and fetch the correct FileSystem impl. No? You need to set `fs.defaultFs` to only denote what scheme to pick if one is not specified? May be I am understanding this wrong? 

I acknowledge the FSUtils.getFS() could be changed and made better. May be we can start with how things break today, when we attempt to do something like 

`new HoodieReadClient(jsc, "gcs://path/on/gcs").read(..) ` 

and upsert into hdfs via

```
cfg.withPath("hdfs://path/on/hdfs")
....
new HoodieWriteClient(jsc, cfg).upsert(..) 
```
which is what you are going for IIUC
cc @prazanna please chip in

My thoughts on this:
HoodieWriteConfig can have a withConf(Configuration c) and FSUtils.getFS can be formatted for accept a conf which is either passed as the conf set or new Configuration(). 

Clients can create a conf when they create a HoodieWriteConfig. 
cc @@n3nash - who was also looking into this.

Okay. yes we need control of the config object to infer the URI/scheme. What I was saying was always passing the `basePath` with the scheme prefixed, instead of relying on the inference in FileSystem class based on `fs.defaultFS` . 

I am open to passing in the `Configuration` either via a configuration property like what Prasanna mentioned, if we don't really want to always prefix basePath with the right scheme . Does that help clarify?

Nevermind - just saw your comment.
HoodieRealtimeRecordReader now uses the CompactedRecordScanner to compact and read log files, PR https://github.com/uber/hoodie/pull/180 fixes this.
/cc @vinothchandar @prazanna @zqureshi
